sentences.sentence: At last they came to a very small and poorly-built hut( 茅舍 ), and she said,
"What a wretched( 讨厌的 ) hut is this I see
And who on earth can its owner be?”
The man answered,
“That is my house and yours, where we must live together.”
She had to bend( 俯身 ) down before she could go in at the door.
“Where are the servants?” asked the King’s daughter.
“What servants?” answered the beggar-man.
“You must do everything yourself. Make a fire quickly, and put on water, and cook me some food; I am very tired.”
But the King’s daughter understood nothing about fire-making and cooking, and the beggar-man had to help her in order to manage it at all.
And when they had eaten their poor meal, they went to bed. But the man woke up his wife very early in the morning to clean the house.
For a few days they lived like this, until they came to the end of their food.
“Wife,” said the man, “you can’t just live here earning( 挣得 ) nothing: you must make baskets.”
So he went out and cut willows( 柳条 ), and brought them home.
She began to weave( 编织 ) them, but the hard stems( 茎 ) wounded( （使）受伤 ) her soft hands.
“I see this will not do,” said the man. “You had better( 最好 ) try spinning( 纺线 ).”
So she sat down and tried to spin, but the rough( 粗糙的 ) thread( 线 ) cut her soft fingers, so that the blood flowed( 流 ).
“Look now!” said the man.
“You are no good at any sort of work; I made a bad bargain( 交易 ) when I took you. I will make some clay( 陶土 ) pots( 罐 ). You can go to the market and try to sell them.”
“Oh dear!” thought she.
“What if, while I am selling in the market, people from my father’s kingdom should see me?
How they would laugh at me!”
But she had no choice: it was either that, or else die of hunger.
The first day went well.
Because she was so beautiful, men came and talked to her and bought her pots.
Some of them even gave her money and left the pots behind them.
They lived on that money as long as it lasted, and then the man made a number of new pots.
So she laid out her pots for sale in a corner of the market.
Suddenly a drunken( 醉酒的 ) soldier( 士兵 ) on a horse came rushing by, and rode straight through her pots, breaking them into a thousand pieces.
She could do nothing but cry helplessly( 无助地 ).
“Oh dear, what will become of me?” cried she.
“What will my husband say?” and she hurried home and told him of her misfortune( 不幸 ).
“Who ever heard of such a thing as sitting in the corner of a market with clay pots—no wonder they got broken!” said the beggar( 乞丐 ).
“Now stop crying. I see you are not fit for any regular( 寻常的 ) work. I have been asking at your father’s castle( 城堡 ) if they want a servant in their kitchen, and they say they don’t mind taking you.
That way, at least you will get some food.”
